review_title: Things seem to consistently get worse
job_title: Enrollment Services Department in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
The pay is a little above average and the pro fit sharing is nice, but after working there for a couple of years, it does not go up as much.

The healthcare plan is very good. It might be better than the actual university's plan.

The employees (non-management) are good people.
cons:
The only way to move up in the company or to gain respect of upper management is to play the game...and to play the game at DeL, you have to be a "loyal lap dog". Depending on what department you work in, there is a lot of workload expected of employees, and the employees see little compensation. It seems like the 99% of the company work their tails off to expand the pockets of upper management (the 1%).

Favoritism is used with most of management. Upper management will encourage employees for feedback, but will only listen to feedback that feeds upper management's egos. Management does not want to be questioned when it comes to their decisions. 

In recent years, the turnover ratio is very high.

review_title: A top-heavy, gossip laden community where the worker bees are overworked to feed the multiple queens.
pros: Benefits are good, if you can get them. Also, the emails with multiple misspellings and wrong use of cliche phrases from management provide great amusement. Most of the lower level staff are nice people who are just trying to put their time in.
cons: The only way to get anything from management is to be a giant brown noser, as their egos are all so huge they don't realize employees are using this as a tactic and not the truth. Favoritism runs amok that it's often hard to remember to not hate the player, but hate the game (and the company environment). Gossip and HR violations are rampant, but employees don't feel comfortable coming forward because management finds out the whistle blowers and finds ways to make their lives miserable. Management is inflexible and only ask for opinions to make employees feel that changes might be coming soon. Everyone is so bitter that it is impossible to maintain a positive work environment.

review_title: Glorified call center, dead end job
pros:
The people in the department are fantastic. 
Salary is decent for what the position is. 
Health benefits.
cons:
With recent changes, there is a lot of micro-managing, and miscommunication. 
Upper management was so eager to implement new ideas without thinking anything all the way through, consulting the team on their thoughts or input, or how this would affect staff morale. 
Nothing in this office is thought through. 
Managers do not involve staff in decisions whatsoever
PTO could be a lot better
Only paid once a month
Have to work two late nights a week, this is non-negotiable and more senior members get to choose which days they work and are not typically open to switching nights.


I would recommend staying away

pros: Near public transit and there are many dining options to choose from
cons:
Drexel University Online (DUO) is surviving off of Drexel's reputation. Many people are attracted to DUO because of its name association with Drexel. Working for DUO is like working in an alternate universe. I was naive to think many of the negative reviews about DUO were from disgruntled employees. The reviews are spot on.  

Cons: 
High turnover 
Moral from coworkers is extremely bad
Management lacks vision and integrity 
No opportunities for growth for most positions 
Archaic policies
Employees work in silos
Lacks a sincere commitment to employing a diverse workforce 
Poor work culture 
Not eligible for Drexel benefits  such as tuition remission and home ownership assistance.

review_title: What should have been a foot in the door ended up being a dead end
pros:
Easy commute via public transport
For an urban-campus it is very nice
Most co-workers  were nice and just as equally frustrated!
Very generous with how much time off you accumulate  and you don't have to use vacation time during winter break (although "volunteers" are required to come in each day)
My manger was low key and approachable 
You will never have to take work home with you
cons:
As many others have revealed, this position functions more so like a call center than a higher education institution, as you are mainly cold calling prospective students.  Under the current protocol, expect to have to call inquires four times... while on occasion you do connect with really eager students, often times it voicemail after voicemail after voicemail. Also, calling applicants over and over to check in on their the status of their documents becomes tedious for both you and the student. 

While many students may prefer to communicate via email, this role does not take this into account Your performance and success will be based off of how many calls you make, how long you are on the phone, and what percent of inbound calls you answer (so if you go to the bathroom or get water and miss a call it's counted AGAINST you).  

If you don't meet the standards set by a management (which most of us don't), it doesn't matter; you will not lose your job. It's a way for management to appear they are helping us "grow" and "develop"... instead of really helping us pursue what true passion we may have in higher education. 

The fact of the matter is, these numbers are arbitrary and we instead should be focused on meeting enrollment numbers and connecting with on-campus resources to ensure we are all on the same page. This department is completely separate to on-campus, hence very little opportunity to connect with other staff for networking. 

Internally, you will not have the opportunity to do anything else besides make calls, then make more calls. How this role has been structured is a waste of time and resources and I do not see that changing any time soon. 

Take this job if you are desperate for one, but do not expect to get much out of it. Based on my disappointing experience, I would not recommend Drexel as a place to work or a place to study.

pros: Educational benefits are great ($12,000 each year). This is a very "cushy" position. If you are looking for a position with close to no responsibility and no advancement--this could work for you.
cons: Leadership will barely interact or speak to you. We are a small group at DUO, yet leadership could pass you in the hallway and they wouldn't know you worked for DUO. As an enrollment counselor, you work first hand with students, so you are able to recognize when a system works and when it doesn't..regardless, your concerns are never taken seriously by the leadership you work under. You are not viewed as valuable employees by the rest of the university and will be often be referred to as the "call center." Director tends to be very inpersonable and doesn't interact with staff much. Most of the leadership that has been there many years doesn't like to hear suggestions or new ideas. They prefer you stay in your lane, regardless of you expertise. Two days a week, you work 11am-8pm, which is a waste of time and upon being hired I was told these were "flexible"--they are not. You will be required to work these hours. Underpaid, being asked to "volunteer" for extra duties. In 2 years, we've never had a raise, not even for cost of living. You may be lucky enough to land a job on campus, but most people find it to be a dead end job and they leave the DUO.

pros: Good benefits, profit sharing (when it was a thing) was great, friendly people, fun staff events.
cons: Profit sharing made up a sizable portion of your income, so take home pay is much less than industry averages. Upper level management was constantly changing. Very difficult for change to take effect and little room for advancement.

review_title: Still pretty bad with poor leadership
pros: The benefits package is pretty great and probably better than the industry standard. They also have tuition reimbursement options for online programs.
cons:
I was here for about a year and experienced the old and new leadership. Other reviewers were right on target about previous leadership being the death of this company. They had huge egos and only cared about each other. There were a lot of HR violations swept under the rug and it was a pretty terrible time at the company. New President Dr. Susan Aldridge hired new leadership and I was anxiously waiting to see what would happen. Minus the HR violations the new leadership team is a lot like the old one. 

Not much has really changed. Almost every day you’re told how you aren’t doing your job properly but are given no clear direction on what the goals are or how to achieve them. Our ideas aren’t taken seriously and leadership provides no solutions. Leadership likes to talk…a lot…and it’s clear they have no idea what they are talking about. And the proverbial grape vine is at an all time high. A lot of the rumors are pretty vicious and childish.
 
We’re constantly hearing about the merger and budget cuts and it seems like doomsday is approaching. When I started two rounds of layoffs happened. By the time I left two more happened. Yet we are constantly told we are “growing”. People who had been at the company for years have left. That’s a sign right there to stay away. They also eliminated profit share (aka bonus) and professional development reimbursement. And our annual raise in December didn’t happen. Throughout the past year things kept getting worse, even with the new changes, so it was time for me to go.

Oh…people who are still there told me the Keurig options have been drastically reduced! We used to have a ton of options but they got rid of a lot of it. There is zero motivation to work here.
